What's the issue? 8080 is getting amended to the repo URL.

Nginx config is the reason? It looks clean..

Reproduced the issue - verified the values.yaml file -- "there is an internal redirect in place"

ssloffload is marked to false @ the Nginx layer!!!

Enabled SSL offloading at the Nginx level - it updated the template of the Nginx (Artifactory) configuration to remove the $port variable.

Issue is resolved - Customer is happy with the explanation on the usage of Nginx & resolution.

Over the session
column18: we further discussed the TIME_WAIT and ESTABLISHED count on the Artifactory port 8081
column19: where we could notice a larger amount of TIME_WAIT on the netstat output. Ideally
column20: to observe a high TIME_WAIT is normal and the reason is
column21: TIME_WAIT is the state after a socket has closed
column22: used by the kernel to keep track of packets that may have got lost and turned up late. Usually
column23:
the high number of TIME_WAIT connections is a symptom of getting lots of short-lived connections and you may can safely ignore this.


I have also attached the link to external articles for your reference describing this behaviour

  1. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33177370/what-could-cause-so-many-time-wait-connections-to-be-open
  2. https://serverfault.com/questions/23385/huge-amount-of-time-wait-connections-says-netstat
  3. https://newbedev.com/huge-amount-of-time-wait-connections-says-netstat

Further
column24:
we also generated a few thread dumps over the call and verified if there are any suspicious timouts occuring at the thread dumps and we could not identify any unsafe packets by the thread id which could cause slowness or impact the Application.

Hi Azat
column41:
It was a pleasure meeting you today.


During the session
column42: you further elaborated about the current situation where after upgrading your staging Artifactory instance from 7.19.4 to 7.27.10
column43:
Access was no longer able to run queries against the database.


As you mentioned that you’re using an HA PostgreSQL setup along with ‘pgpool’
column44: I informed you that Artifactory does not support HA DB setups and is specifically known to cause troubles when using ‘pgpool’
column46:
open Jira tickets:


RTMID-14892 - Artifactory create database schema don't work with pgpool

RTMID-12614 - Add support for database load balancing

RTMID-21479 - Artifactory feature request to gracefully handle HA database pod/node failures that cause JDBC connection to break mid connection with artifactory. 


Additionally
column47: you confirmed that when configuring Artifactory with the direct PostgreSQL address (bypassing ‘pgpool’)
column48:
everything worked as expected.


As you mentioned that you were already considering moving to non-HA database setup
column49: we agreed that the best approach would be migrating to a single database prior to the dev/production upgrade attempt. Furthermore
column50:
I mentioned that a database migration is a fairly simple process which consists of a DB-dump + import and connection string/credentials updates (system.yaml).


Finally
column52: I have thoroughly reviewed the source code differences between Artifactory 7.19.4 and 7.27.10. It appears that within the large number of commits that took place between these versions
column53:
one commit includes changes to the flyway library which directly affect the Access <> PostgreSQL communication.


While I can’t get into specifics
column54:
it’s very likely that these changes are what's causing the different behavior with ‘pgpool’.


I hope this has been helpful. Please let us know if you have any follow up questions

  • Discussed the next roadmap items - Migrating to new NFS and Cold storage Artifactory
  • License bucket management - case 186434 raised
column87:
action items on DB fo now
  • Projects - estimated 200 projects to be used
column88:
best practices shared with splitting up the monolithic local repository for each team and keeping monolithic remote repository for the entire teams with regular cleaning the cached unused artifacts.
  • Migration to RHEL8 from RHEL7 - No OS upgrades therefore the migration is to be performed for all the 2 nodes Artifactory instances to RHEL8. Two ways migration discussed:
    • Have a new Artifactory 7.27.9 (exact version) with Linux archive in the new RHEL8 server and copy over the etc folder and start
    • Have a new HA Artifactory node in RHEL8
column89:
connect it with the current 2 nodes Artifactory running on RHEL7 and keep the traffic to the new Artifactory node and gradually move to the new RHEL8.

I hope the call was helpful. I will create a simple roadmap document and will share it with you so that we can have some estimated ETAs.

  • Deployment cycles differ per project from once in a month to daily. This is where Artifactory downtimes become unacceptable and are disturbing the release process causing the need for a rollback and customer dissatisfaction.

column392: sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-size: 10pt;">.  This long-awaited enhancement automates the lifecycle management of your binaries - archiving artifacts you need to retain while lowering your storage costs in the process.  The outcome is a significant improvement of the usability of your primary storage while preserving the metadata.  The initial release includes integrations with AWS Glacier and local storage.  If your storage consumption exceeds 10TB
column393: let’s discuss how to implement this new functionality ASAP.

What was demonstrated and discussed during the session

  • The customer wants to move to cloud they are finding it difficult to manage Arti/xray based on their “rehydrating” process (described earlier). 
  • The call was about the diff between Self managed and cloud from tech perspective and answering their questions.
  • We also had an in-depth discussion on the migration strategies moving from self managed to cloud. 
  • The call lasted for 30 mins.
